So the hospital wants to optimize patient care by reducing waiting times for appointments. They have 20 doctors now, and each sees an average of 15 patients per day. They plan to hire more doctors to increase the daily number of patients seen by 25%. I need to figure out how many more doctors they need to hire and how this will affect the average waiting time for appointments, assuming the demand stays the same.

First, I should find out how many patients the hospital currently sees every day. If there are 20 doctors and each sees 15 patients per day, then the total number of patients seen per day is:

20 doctors * 15 patients/docto r= 300 patients/day

Now, they want to increase this number by 25%. So, the increase in the number of patients would be:

300 patients/day * 25% = 75 patients/day

Therefore, the new total number of patients to be seen per day would be:

300 patients/day + 75 patients/day = 375 patients/day

Each doctor still sees an average of 15 patients per day, so to find out how many doctors are needed to see 375 patients per day, I can divide the total number of patients by the number of patients per doctor:

375 patients/day ÷ 15 patients/doctor = 25 doctors

They already have 20 doctors, so the number of additional doctors needed is:

25 doctors - 20 doctors = 5 doctors
